title: 110_hr5962
content: The "Keep Our Homes Act of 2008" is cited as the short title. It includes a temporary deduction for certain mortgage counseling under section 224 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Keep Our Homes Act of 2008" includes a deduction for qualified mortgage counseling up to $500 per year, provided by an FHA-accredited organization before obtaining a loan on the taxpayer's principal residence. The deduction is not allowed for amounts paid after December 31, 2012. The deduction for qualified mortgage counseling up to $500 per year, provided by an FHA-accredited organization, is not allowed for amounts paid after December 31, 2012. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2007. A temporary deduction for upside-down mortgages is introduced in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. In general, an individual can deduct 20 percent of the excess acquisition indebtedness for their principal residence over its valuation for real property tax assessments. The deduction is limited to $5,000 per year and is not allowed for fraudulently obtained mortgages. This deduction is not applicable for amounts paid or incurred after December 31, 2009. The deduction under this section for upside-down mortgages is not allowed after December 31, 2009. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2007. A new section allows for a credit for certain home purchases. A credit is allowed for individuals purchasing a qualified principal residence, equal to 10% of the purchase price or $7,500 ($9,000 in high-cost areas). The credit is divided equally over two taxable years. Limitations include purchases made after the enactment date but before 12 months after. The credit for purchasing a qualified principal residence is limited to purchases made after the enactment date and before 12 months after. The credit amount is reduced based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income. The credit for purchasing a qualified principal residence is limited based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income, which is the adjusted gross income increased by certain exclusions. The credit allowed for any taxable year is capped by the excess of the regular tax liability plus certain other taxes over the sum of allowable credits. The credit allowed for purchasing a qualified principal residence is limited based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income. The credit for any taxable year cannot exceed the excess of the regular tax liability plus certain other taxes over the sum of allowable credits. Additionally, a one-time only rule applies where no credit is allowed for the purchase of another qualified principal residence in the same taxable year. The credit for purchasing a qualified principal residence is limited by the taxpayer's income. No credit is allowed if it has been claimed for another residence in the same year. A qualified principal residence is defined as the main residence purchased by the taxpayer. No double benefit is allowed if a credit is claimed under another section. The credit for purchasing a qualified principal residence is limited by the taxpayer's income and cannot be claimed if a credit has been used for another residence in the same year. A qualified principal residence is the main residence purchased by the taxpayer, and no double benefit is allowed if a credit is claimed under another section. If the taxpayer disposes of the qualified principal residence within 24 months of purchase or fails to occupy it as their principal residence, the remaining portion of the credit will be disallowed in the taxable year of disposition or non-occupation. The credit for purchasing a qualified principal residence is subject to limitations based on the taxpayer's income and previous use of credits. If the taxpayer disposes of the residence within 24 months or fails to occupy it as their main residence, the remaining credit will be disallowed in the taxable year. Special rules apply for joint purchases, with adjustments for married individuals filing separately and unmarried individuals sharing a residence. The credit for purchasing a qualified principal residence is subject to limitations based on the taxpayer's income and previous use of credits. The total amount of credits allowed to individuals cannot exceed $7,000. Rules similar to those for purchase and reporting requirements apply. If a credit is allowed for a residence purchase, the basis of the residence is reduced by the amount of the credit. Conforming amendments include adding section 25E to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The basis of a residence is reduced by the amount of the credit allowed for its purchase. Conforming amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 include adding section 25E. Section 904(i) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to include section 25E. Section 1016 is also amended to reference section 25E(g), and section 1400C(d)(2) is updated to include section 25E. Additionally, a clerical amendment is made to the table of sections to include section 25E after section 25D. SEC. 25E provides a credit for certain home purchases, effective for purchases in taxable years after the enactment of the Act. The amendment is subject to the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001. Additionally, there is a temporary additional standard deduction for real property taxes for nonitemizers under SEC. 5. The amendment adds a real property tax deduction for taxable years 2008 and 2009, allowing a deduction of eligible state and local real property taxes up to $500 ($1,000 for joint returns). The amendment allows a deduction for eligible state and local real property taxes up to $500 ($1,000 for joint returns) for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2007. SEC. 6. TEMPORARY EXCLUSION OF UNEMPLOYMENT COMPENSATION FROM GROSS INCOME. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to exclude unemployment compensation from gross income for individuals in 2008 and 2009. Effective for amounts received after December 31, 2007.
